Technical Assistance Report
Project Number: 43142 
Capacity Development Technical Assistance (CDTA) 
December 2009 
 
 
 
 
Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste: Statistical and 
Macroeconomic Capacity Building 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Timor-Leste  is  a  young  nation  that  faces  significant  challenges  in  rebuilding  its 
infrastructure,  strengthening  the  civil  administration,  and  generating  jobs  for  young  people 
entering the workforce. In late 2007, the new government announced plans aimed at increasing 
spending, reducing poverty, and improving the country's infrastructure. These plans will require 
better statistical capability for national policy formulation and to help measure the impact of 
government development policies on society and the economy. 
 
2.  The  Timor-Leste  country  operations  business  plan  2008–2010 1  of  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) aims to build the government's capacity to manage and deliver 
quality  basic  social  services.  A  country  partnership  strategy  for  2009–2012  is  now  being 
finalized.2 This includes a focus on building state capacity, particularly in core areas of public 
administration (including statistics). The Government of Timor-Leste has reaffirmed its desire for 
ADB  to  assist  in  this  area,  including  in  statistics  capacity  building  and  macroeconomic 
management within the Ministry of Finance. 
 
3.  The technical assistance (TA) will support the National Directorate of Statistics (NDS) to 
manage Timor-Leste's statistical system and enhance the capacity of the National Directorate of 
Macro-economy to provide macroeconomic advice and analysis. Both directorates are part of 
the General Directorate of Policy Analysis and Research within the Ministry of Finance. The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
4.  In conceptualizing the assistance, extensive consultations were conducted during the 
preparation of a long-term statistical capacity building TA program for Timor-Leste.3 A country 
consultation  mission  took  place  in  June  2009  and  held  preliminary  discussions  with  the 
government on the TA. Further consultations were conducted in September 2009.4 The major 
agreements  with  the  government  on  the  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  implementation 
arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of reference are reflected in this TA 
paper. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
5.  In addition to the increasing demand for statistics for national policy formulation and to 
help measure the impact of development policies on society and the economy, increasing 
international cooperation and globalization have created a demand for statistics that will allow 
Timor-Leste to compare its national economic and social indicators against other countries. A 
primary  requirement  for  national  benchmarking  is  that  the  national  statistical  system  can 
produce  high-quality  information  that  is  consistent  with  that  gathered  for  other  developing 
countries. The production of Timor-Leste statistics must be as timely as that of other countries in 
Asia and the Pacific so that the country can measure its economic and social performance 
relative to them. Timor-Leste, despite its small size and relatively limited capacity, must develop 
and maintain a statistical system that supports economic monitoring and policy analysis and 
facilitates international comparison. 
 
6.  In addition, the requirement for diverse information has created many new demands and 
responsibilities for national statistical agencies. In the past, much statistical work focused on 
meeting the needs of key domestic users and international organizations. Now many see a key

role for statistics in the evolution of a more open civil society. The role of statistical agencies is 
gradually changing from the basic tasks of collecting statistics to assisting users to make 
appropriate use of them. This means providing more analysis and interpretation of key trends. 
Traditional paper publications are being replaced by more detailed data in electronic form. 
 
7.  The statistical system in Timor-Leste is not currently capable of responding to these 
demands. The system lags behind in terms of relevance, periodicity and timeliness, except for 
the production of the consumer price index (CPI) and trade statistics. Only the CPI, trade, fiscal, 
monetary and banking statistics are published regularly. National accounts, labor statistics, 
poverty statistics and others are not produced regularly. The NDS lacks funding and its staff are 
not well trained, especially in survey design, data processing, and analysis. On-the-job training 
has been successfully implemented for CPI and trade statistics and needs to be extended to 
other areas. 
 
8.  Under  a  TA  on  Statistical  Capacity  Building  in  the  Asia  and  Pacific  Region,5 ADB 
assessed  the  statistical  capacity,  constraints,  and  needs  of  developing  member  countries 
(DMCs); identified DMCs that were statistically very weak; and developed separate long-term 
statistical capacity building TA programs for some of them. Timor-Leste was one of four DMCs 
identified as requiring technical assistance in the first phase.6 In Mongolia, Nepal, and Timor-
Leste,  a  diagnostic  study  of  the  countries'  statistical  systems  was  undertaken  in  close 
consultation with the national statistics offices, and other major stakeholders, and a long-term 
statistical  capacity  building  TA  program  was  developed.  More  recently,  the  Timor-Leste 
government, with the assistance of the World Bank and other donors, initiated a project to 
develop a statistical work plan. The resulting report reinforces the approach identified in the 
long-term statistical capacity building TA program.7 
 
9.  The  statistical  capacity  building  TA  program  for  Timor-Leste  (footnote  3)  has  the 
following components: (i) build the management capacity of the management of the NDS and 
the national statistical system, (ii) define and develop a statistical work program for the NDS, (iii) 
improve national accounts statistics,8 (iv) undertake a labor force survey, (v) establish new 
statistics legislation, (vi) undertake staff development, (vii) improve dissemination of statistical 
data, and (viii) establish a basic information technology infrastructure. Each of the components 
in the program is described below.  
 
10.  Build  management  capacity.  Building  the  managerial  capacity  of  the  NDS 
management and the line ministries is a priority. This will improve coordination across the 
national statistical system and encourage data sharing. Under the statistical capacity building 
TA program, this component has three subcomponents: (i) provide professional management 
training to the director of NDS, (ii) conduct basic management training for senior statistical 
officials, and (iii) organize study visits for senior management of NDS. The World Bank intends 
to  recruit  a  consultant  under  its  Public  Financial  Management  Capacity  Building  Program 
(PFMCBP) to strengthen the institutional capacity of the NDS. 
 
11.  Define and develop a statistical work program. At the time the statistical capacity 
building TA program was being prepared, there was a requirement to specify what statistical

work was being undertaken and what was planned over the next 3 years. Further, there was an 
urgent  need  to  determine  the  statistical  system's  users'  priority  needs,  including  the 
requirements needed from such sources as the national development plan and the general data 
dissemination system. While further work remains to be undertaken under this component 
through the completion of the statistical work plan (2010–2019)9 and other similar reports, 
progress is being made. 
 
12.  Improve  national  accounts.  Timor-Leste  does  not  have  any  system  of  compiling 
regular national accounts statistics. Only ad hoc estimates of gross domestic product (GDP) are 
available.  There  is  a  need  to  provide  updated  estimates  for  recent  years  and  build  a 
comprehensive program for establishing a system of national accounts in the medium and long 
terms. Existing donor support has been provided to various initiatives under this component. 
This includes ongoing support by a national accounts advisor to the NDS under the World 
Bank's PFMCBP. The support started in April 2009 and will last for 1 year with a possibility of 
further extension. The government has sought ADB assistance to enhance data collection on 
business enterprises and agriculture to improve national accounts statistics. 
 
13.  Undertake a labor force survey. The high unemployment rate in Timor-Leste poses 
significant challenges for development in the country. Therefore, it is important to have accurate 
and reliable data on the labor force in Timor-Leste to devise strategies to reduce unemployment. 
The International Labour Organization is currently providing assistance in this area.10 
 
14.  Establish new statistics legislation. The present law governing statistics in Timor-
Leste is weak and incomplete. There is an urgent and high-priority need for new legislation that 
can safeguard statistical independence, the secrecy of the information collected, and the rights 
and obligations of statistical officers. The World Bank proposes to provide assistance for the 
drafting of statistics legislation.11 
 
15.  Undertake staff development. The staff of NDS have limited capacity in areas such as 
survey design, survey management, data processing and analysis, and there is considerable 
need for capacity building in all these areas. The English language skills of the staff need to be 
significantly improved because most statistical documentation and international meetings are 
conducted in English. Only a few staff have appropriate tertiary education.  
 
16.  Improve  dissemination  of  statistical  data. Data dissemination is very limited and 
rudimentary. There is a significant need to ensure that statistics are released in a usable form 
and  in  a  timely  fashion  to  users.  Ongoing  support  is  being  provided  by  a  long-term 
dissemination advisor and a local publications officer under the sponsorship of Portuguese 
Cooperation and the United Nations Population Fund respectively. 
 
17.  Establish  a  basic  information  technology  infrastructure. The use of information 
technology in statistical work in Timor-Leste is very rudimentary, and it needs to be established 
in an effective and efficient way. 
 
18.  In addition to requesting support for implementation of the statistical capacity building TA 
program, the Ministry of Finance has requested ADB support to improve macroeconomic advice

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
19.  The TA is intended to enhance the statistical system in Timor-Leste to enable relevant, 
reliable, regular, and timely statistics to be produced for analysis and dissemination by building 
on  the  long-term  statistical  capacity  building  TA  program.  This  is  to  be  achieved  through 
targeted interventions in priority areas, building on previous work by ADB and other donors. The 
selection of priority areas was based on discussions with the government. In addition, the TA is 
designed to enhance the capacity of the National Directorate of Macro-economy to provide 
macroeconomic advice and analysis. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
20.  The TA will focus on building the capacity of the staff of the NDS by supporting them to 
design  and  conduct  a  business  activity  survey  (which  will  include  the  development  of  a 
statistical business register) and an agricultural production survey.12 The TA will support the 
collection, validation, processing, analysis, use, and dissemination of the survey data by the 
NDS. Training covering basic statistical skills such as data collection, validation, processing, 
analysis, dissemination, and decision-making as well as computer skills including the use of MS 
Office and specialized statistical software packages will be provided. 
 
21.  The key data to be collected or calculated as part of the surveys will be those largely 
required for computing GDP.13 A key component of the surveys will involve the provision of 
hands-on training and mentoring to NDS staff so they have the capacity to conduct subsequent 
surveys without the assistance of development partners. The government has indicated that it is 
increasing the budget for NDS to enable it to fund future annual surveys. To support these 
efforts, it will be recruiting three or four more permanent staff for the Department of Economic 
Statistics (part of the NDS) in 2010. This will help in the development of a system to compile 
regular national accounts statistics. 
 
22.  In addition, the TA will (i) establish a twinning arrangement with an appropriate nearby 
government statistical agency that can provide ongoing support and expertise to enhance the 
capacity of the management of the NDS through activities such as at least one study visit, and 
(ii) support English language skills training for staff of the NDS by utilizing a local training 
provider to provide in-house tailored English language classes and by supporting the acquisition 
of relevant English language training software. The study visit and twinning arrangement will be 
part of a long-term partnering arrangement with a nearby government statistical agency that will 
ensure the long-term sustainability of the TA. 
 
23.  The TA will also support the Ministry of Finance to provide macroeconomic advice and 
analysis. This resource will be available to provide rapid analysis on key economic issues as 
they arise and as opportunities for effective engagement present themselves.

C.  Cost and Financing 
24.  The TA is estimated to cost $630,000 equivalent. The government has requested ADB 
financing of $560,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB's Technical 
Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The government will finance the balance of the cost, 
equivalent to $70,000, through provision of office accommodation, counterpart staff, logistical 
and publishing support for the surveys, and other in-kind contributions. Appendix 2 provides 
details of the cost estimates and financing plan. The proceeds of the TA will be disbursed in line 
with the Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook.14 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
25.  The NDS will be the executing agency for the TA and will implement the statistical 
components, while ADB's Special Office in Timor-Leste will be the implementing agency for the 
macroeconomic  component.  Where  appropriate,  ADB's  Special  Office  in  Timor-Leste  will 
coordinate with the NDS in implementing the statistical component. The government will appoint 
a TA focal point who will be responsible for coordinating with and providing progress reports to 
ADB. The government will also provide partial funding for surveys to be conducted under the TA 
and to provide ADB with the data and results of these surveys.15 
 
26.  The TA will be implemented over 30 months, starting in February 2010. The TA will 
finance  up  to  19  person-months  of  international  consulting  services.  The  international 
consultants will comprise: (i) statistics expert and team leader (international, 6 person-months, 
intermittent); (ii) business activity survey advisor (international, 5 person-months, intermittent); 
(iii) agricultural production activity survey advisor (international, 4 person-months, intermittent); 
and  (iv)  economist  (international,  4  person-months,  intermittent).  The  expected  financial 
completion date of the TA is December 2012. 
 
27.  ADB will engage all consultants as individuals in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). The terms of reference for 
consultants are in Appendix 3. Individual consultants are needed, as a single firm may be 
unable to provide consultants with all the required expertise and experience. Procurement will 
be undertaken in accordance with ADB's Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time 
to time). Any equipment that is purchased using the TA budget will be handed over to the 
government after the completion of the TA. 
 
28.  The  TA  will  be  implemented  in  close  cooperation  with  other  agencies  involved  in 
statistics collection. In addition, the TA will work closely with the World Bank's PFMCBP in the 
Ministry  of  Finance,  as  well  as  with  other  development  partners.  The  World  Bank  will 
complement ADB's assistance by supporting the drafting of new statistics legislation and by 
funding  an  advisory  position  within  the  NDS,  along  with  its  broader  efforts  to  improve 
expenditure and revenue management under its PFMCBP. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
29.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $560,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste for Statistical and Macroeconomic 
Capacity Building, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The work under this technical assistance (TA) will be implemented in a phased manner 
over the period 2010–2012. 
 
2.  All consultants will be briefed by staff from the Government of Timor-Leste and the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) prior to commencing work. Consultants will be required to review all 
relevant  literature  prior  to  beginning  work,  including  the  Report  on  Long-Term  Statistical 
Capacity Building for Timor-Leste,1 A Statistical Work Plan,2 and Review and Action Plan for the 
Statistical System in Timor-Leste.3 When carrying out their assignments, they will report to the 
appropriate agencies (i.e., the National Directorate of Statistics (NDS) or National Directorate of 
Macro-economy) within the Ministry of Finance and ADB. 
 
A.  Statistics Expert and Team Leader (international, 6-person months, intermittent) 
3.  The statistics expert and team leader should have extensive experience gained from 
working  in  a  senior  management  role  in  a  national  statistics  agency  (or  equivalent)  and 
extensive knowledge of the capacity of national statistical systems around the region. He or she 
should have a strong theoretical background, wide expertise, and sufficient practical experience 
in such areas as national accounts, undertaking of surveys, and dissemination of statistics. 
Experience in leading a team of consultants in implementing statistical capacity building TA 
projects will be an advantage. 
 
4.  Working under the guidance of ADB and the NDS within the Ministry of Finance, and 
working closely with NDS staff, the statistics expert will have overall responsibility for developing 
and  implementing  the statistical components  of the  TA by  supporting  the  completion  of  a 
business activity survey and agricultural production survey. Integral to this role will be the 
provision of training, knowledge transfer, and mentoring. 
 
5.  In addition, the statistics expert and team leader will: 
 
(i)  set up a twinning arrangement with an appropriate nearby national statistical 
office,  
(ii)  organize at least one study visit to the partner national statistical office, 
(iii)  put in place the arrangements to support English language skills training for staff 
of the NDS by utilizing a local training provider to provide in-house tailored 
English language classes,  
(iv)  provide guidance to the management of NDS on the management of a national 
statistical office,  
(v)  work with ADB and NDS to select the consultants for the various assignments for 
the statistical component of the TA, 
(vi)  help to organize and conduct the inception, concluding and other workshops for 
the TA, and 
(vii)  submit a report detailing the type of assistance to be provided in a follow-up TA 
to ADB and NDS at a time to be determined by both agencies.

6.  The statistics expert will also undertake the role of team leader and in this role will: 
 
(i)  ensure the expectations of the government and ADB for the delivery of the TA 
are well understood and articulated to other team members; 
(ii)  coordinate  the  work  and  inputs  of  the  consultancy  team,  and  consult  with 
relevant members of the government; 
(iii)  act as the primary interface with the government to ensure the appropriate and 
timely delivery of TA objectives; 
(iv)  provide leadership and guidance to the consultancy team, ensuring the quality 
and timeliness of all elements of the TA; 
(v)  coordinate with other development partners and advisors in the NDS as required 
to ensure no duplication of statistical aid; 
(vi)  ensure all consultant inputs are directed by a work plan; and 
(vii)  maintain close contact with the government and the TA project officer. 
 
B.  Business Activity Survey Consultant (international, 5 person-months, intermittent) 
7.  The business activity survey consultant should have a strong theoretical background, 
wide  expertise,  and  sufficient  practical  experience  in  survey  methodology.  Experience  in 
developing statistical business registers and conducting business activity surveys in developing 
countries around the region will be an asset. He or she should also have a good knowledge of 
national accounting and its concepts and how to incorporate the results of the survey into 
estimates of national accounts for Timor-Leste. The international consultant is expected to lead 
by example, adopt a hands-on approach when carrying out the assignment and work in a 
cooperative manner with the staff and advisors of NDS and the statistics expert and team leader. 
He or she should also be willing to provide training to the staff of NDS on the various steps and 
methodology of conducting the survey, data validation, processing and analysis, and report-
writing  during  the  assignment  so  that  they  are  able  to  conduct  subsequent  surveys 
independently. 
 
8.  In particular, the business activity survey consultant will undertake the following tasks: 
 
(i)  develop a statistical business register; 
(ii)  use the statistical business register to determine the survey methodology along 
with the objectives, scope, and sampling frames of the survey for estimating 
gross output, intermediate inputs, value added, and other data items;  
(iii)  develop  appropriate  survey  instruments,  including  the  questionnaire  for  the 
survey;  
(iv)  prepare a timetable for the survey in consultation with the staff and advisors of 
NDS and the statistics expert and team leader; 
(v)  if  necessary,  conduct  a  pilot  survey  to  test  the  appropriateness  of  the 
questionnaire; 
(vi)  prepare an appropriate tabulation plan; 
(vii)  provide training to NDS staff on the various aspects of conducting the survey,

C.  Agricultural  Production  Survey  Consultant  (international,  4  person-months, 
intermittent) 
9.  The  agricultural  production  survey  consultant  should  have  a  strong  theoretical 
background,  wide  expertise,  and  sufficient  practical  experience  in  survey  methodology. 
Experience in conducting agriculture production surveys in developing countries in the region 
will be an asset. He or she should also have a good knowledge of national accounting and its 
concepts and how to incorporate the results of the survey into estimates of national accounts for 
Timor-Leste. The international consultant is expected to lead by example, adopt a hands-on 
approach when carrying out the assignment and work in a cooperative manner with the staff 
and advisors of NDS and the statistics expert and team leader. He or she should also be willing 
to provide training to the staff of NDS on the various steps and methodology of conducting the 
survey, data validation, processing and analysis, and report writing during the assignment so 
that they are able to conduct subsequent surveys independently. 
 
10.  In particular, the agricultural production survey consultant will undertake the following 
tasks: 
 
(i)  determine  the  survey  methodology  along  with  the  objectives,  scope,  and 
sampling frames of the survey for estimating gross output, intermediate inputs, 
value added, and other data items;  
(ii)  develop  appropriate  survey  instruments,  including  the  questionnaire  for  the 
survey;  
(iii)  explore  the  feasibility  of  conducting  the  survey  at  the  same  time  as  the 
agriculture census which may be conducted in 2011 to reduce the burden on 
respondents; 
(iv)  prepare a timetable for the survey in consultation with the staff and advisors of  
NDS and the statistics expert and team leader; 
(v)  if  necessary,  conduct  a  pilot  survey  to  test  the  appropriateness  of  the 
questionnaire; 
(vi)  prepare an appropriate tabulation plan; 
(vii)  provide training to NDS staff on the various aspects of conducting the survey, 
including selection of samples, design of questionnaires, data collection, data 
validation, processing and analysis, report-writing and dissemination of results, 
and use of MS Office and specialized statistical software packages for survey 
purposes;  
(viii)  assist NDS in conducting the survey and preparing the survey report which 
should include an assessment of the impact on estimates of GDP arising from 
the incorporation of the survey results; 
(ix)  submit the survey report to ADB and NDS at a time to be determined by both 
agencies; 
(x)  if necessary, help to organize and participate in a workshop to disseminate the 
survey results; and 
(xi)  perform other related tasks as assigned by ADB.
